lines.text: You're not going to use the story, Mr. Scott?
No, sir. This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.
[last lines]
Nothing's too good for the man who shot Liberty Valance.
Whoa, take 'er easy there, Pilgrim.
[Doniphon has just faced down Valance in the diner]
Well, now; I wonder what scared 'em off?

[poking fun at Stoddard for his idealism]
You know what scared 'em - the spectacle of law and order here, risin' up out of the gravy and the mashed potatoes.

[Doniphon has just told Stoddard what really happened the night Liberty Valance was shot]
Hallie's your girl now. Go back in there and take that nomination. You taught her how to read and write; now give her something to read and write about!
You lookin' for trouble, Doniphon?
You aim to help me find some?

[Valance has tripped Rance in the diner, causing him to spill a tray of food]
That's *my* steak, Valance.

[laughing]
You heard him, Dude. Pick it up.
No!
Pilgrim, hold it. I said you, Valance; *you* pick it up.
Three against one, Doniphon.
My boy, Pompey; kitchen door.
[Valance looks and sees Pompey at the door holding a rifle]
I'll get it, Liberty!
[Doniphon kicks Floyd in the face as he bends down to retrieve the tray]
Mr. Peabody's awful hurt and he needs you bad over at his office.
What's the matter, Mr. Marshal? Somebody have an accident?
So that's it, another one of your 'accidents', huh Valance? I'm looking forward to the day when it's you they'll be calling me for.

[tossing Doc a silver dollar]
Paid in advance.

[during voting for the territorial convention]
I'll have the usual, Jack.
The bar is closed, Mister Editor, during voting.
Bar's closed?
You can blame your lawyer friend. He says that's one of the "Fundamental laws of democracy." No exception.
No exceptions for the working press? Why, that's carrying democracy much too far!
[Reese and Floyd are trying to get a lynch mob together after Stoddard kills Valance]
Can't a man have a drink around this town in peace?
[grabs Floyd and throws him through the door]
No one's bothering you, Doniphon.
*You* are.
[Reese goes for his gun, and Doniphon decks him]
Marshal! What are you gettin' paid for? Drag this scum out of here.
You heard him! Now, Kaintuck and High Pockets, I deputize you to give a hand and drag this scum out of here!
Give me that b-b-b-bung st-st-starter!
[grabs Reese and hauls him out]
You tell those ranchers north of the Picketwire that hired you that me, Link Appleyard, run you out of town, and I'll do it again if you ever come back!

[protesting his nomination to the statehood convention]
Good people of Shinbone; I, I'm your conscience, I'm the small voice that thunders in the night, I'm your watchdog who howls against the wolves, I, I'm your father confessor! I - I'm... what else am I?
Town drunk?
I know those law books mean alot to you, but not out here. Out here a man settles his own problems.
You talk too much, think too much. Besides, YOU didn't kill Liberty Valance.

[looking into Doniphon's coffin, angrily]
Where are his boots?
Well, I thought... well, they was an awful nice pair of boots, almost brand new, and I thought...
Put his boots on, Clute. And his gun belt, and his spurs.
Hallie, please! The proprieties concerning the cutlery. Now, how many times have I told you, the fork goes to the left of the plate, and the knife goes...
What's the matter with you? You superstitious or something?
Liberty Valance's the toughest man south of the Picketwire - next to me.

Marshal, I was wrong the other day. But I was reading up on territorial law, and there it is, right there. Now, I'll draw up the complaint, take care of all the legal details - but you *do* have jurisdiction. Says so right there. So next time he sets foot in this town, you'll arrest him.
Anything you say, Mr. Stoddard. I'll be tickled to... death... *what* was that? Arrest *who*?
Liberty Valance.
Arrest Liberty Val... you mean Liberty Valance? Just as I was startin' to get my appetite back.
[Pompey has gone into the saloon after Tom]

[indicating that he can't serve Pompey due to his being black]
Now look, Pompey. You know I...

[drunk]
Who says he can't? Pour yourself a drink, Pompey.
You know I don't drink no drams, Mr. Tom.
I said take a drink.
No, sir. We got a mare in foal, and horses to feed and water. You come on home.
Rance, do you think I could... I mean, grown up and all... do you think I could learn to read?

Why, sure you can, Hallie. Why, there's nothing to it. It'd be... it'd be easy. Can you learn how to read? Why, I can... I can teach you. A smart girl like you? Of course you can learn how to read. Now, do you want to try?
It's awful worrisome not knowing how. I know the Good Book from preacher talk; but it'd be a soul comfort if I could read the words myself.

[at the territorial statehood convention]
The chair recognizes its old friend; that distinguished member of the Fourth Estate, founder, owner, publisher and editor of the Shinbone Star, Mr. Dutton Peabody, Esquire!
founder, owner, editor, and I also sweep out the place.
The jail's only got one cell, and the lock's broke and I sleep in it.

[to Liberty Valance and his gang who have been waiting for him in the newspaper office]
Liberty Valance... and his myrmidons!
It's Liberty! He - he's hurt!
[Doc approaches Valance's body]
It's Liberty.
Whiskey, quick.
Here, sir.

[takes a drink, turns Valances body over with his foot]
Dead.
[walks off]

[in Stoddard's classroom]
How you feeling this morning?
Just fine, fine, fine.
Your head cold?
Uh, no, no. I uh.
[sheepishly removes hat]

[bringing his truant son Herbert to school]
Ain't you goin' to give him a whoppin'?
No, he's too big.
You got a choice, Dishwasher. Either you get out of town, or tonight you be out on that street alone. You be there, and don't make us come and get you.

[to Ransom Stoddard]
Hey, pilgrim! You forgot your pop-gun!
Give me a drink.
Bar's closed.
Just a beer!
The bar's closed.
A beer's not drinking!
One steak for Mr. Peabody, with fixins'.
Steak, beans, potatoes...
And a deep dish apple pie.
Someday he order something different and we all faint dead away.
I don't want to kill him, I just want to put him in jail!
Ohhh...
Courage can be purchased at yon' tavern!

Liberty Valance defeated. D-E-F-E-E... T-E-D? The unsteady hand betrays. What's the matter, Mr. Peabody? Are you afraid? The answer is indub... yes. No courage left. Well, courage can be purchased at yon tavern. But have we credit? That is the question. Have we credit? Well, credit is cheap. Wait for me, old servant of the public weal. Our shining hour is yet to come. As for you, Horace Greeley, go west, old man, and grow young with the country.
Pompey, go find Doc Willoughby. If he's sober, bring him back.
As long as he behaves himself in this town, I ain't got no, ah...
Jurisdiction.
What he said is right. I ain't got none of it.

[shouting]
Hashslinger; you out here?
I'd say that was Liberty Valance there now; wouldn't you?
Yes, I would.
W-w-we'll be seein' you, Mr. Stoddard.
Well, Mr. Professor. I thought you left town. What are you doin' out here?
I'm waiting for Liberty Valance. Why doesn't he come out?
Well, th-th-that's n-n-none of our b-b-b-business.
Poppa - go put your pants on!
Did you know Liberty Valance is in town tonight?
I'd be a poor newspaperman indeed if I didn't know what everybody knows!

[very drunk]
My advice to you as uh...
Coroner.
and uh your personal phys...
Physician!
is to get your supper and go to bed. No charge.

[after a mounted politician working for Langhorne has ridden a horse into the convention and performed rope tricks for the audience]
This is a convention, *not* a rodeo, Langhorne!
[first lines]

[descending from railway carriage and consulting pocket watch]
Thanks, Jason. On time.
go West and grow young with the country!

[Raising his gun]
This time, right between the eyes.
